tries in the world ; the future value of its stock cannot now
he computed without some appearance of exaggeration.—
Nearly every acre of the ground over which it will pass, is
susceptible of cultivation. To say nothing of the region
south of Berwick's Bay, of which I know nothing from personal observation, the parishes of Opelousas and Attakapas
alone, when propel]y developed by this new communication,
will, by their increased commerce wi.h New Orleans, and
their heavy shipments to and from your city, be the means
of paving more than a handsome dividend on the capital
stock ol' the road. How much vacant land remains to be
brought into cultivation in these pari-bes, I am not now able
to sav. But you may form some idea on the subject, when I
tell you that there are in the parish of St. Landry alone
about one million and a half acres of laud, nearly all of which
is susceptible of cultivation, and most admirably adapted lo
the production of sugar. Of this, less than two hundred thousand acres are now cultivated. Immense forests and piai-
ries are yet unredeemed from their primeval condition, by the
industry of man; and, although this parish was one of the
first settled m the state, it is but sparsely populated, and agriculture yet in its very infancy. But the exuberant fertility
ol the soil compensates for the want of the appliances of art
to its tillage : and the husbandman, with the smallest application of agricultural skill, is rewarded annually with a plentiful harvest. And this may serve as a criterion for the remaining parishes, as far as Berwick's Bay. They are all
adapted to the growth of our staple products ; and, under
the prospering influences of the railroad, will constitute the
most wealthy, populous and productive region in Louisiana.
Gentlemen, it would be doing injustice to this beautiful portion of your state, to leave unnoticed its striking geographies features, and its salubrious climate. And were I painter
or poet, I would endeavor to give you a faint idea of its
picturesque scenery, its evergreen groves, its splendid forests,","fullrs":{},"find":"2092.jp2","dmaccess":{},"dmimage":{},"dmcreated":"2012-01-18","dmmodified":"2012-01-18","dmoclcno":{},"dmrecord":"2091","restrictionCode":"1","cdmfilesize":"513183","cdmfilesizeformatted":"0.49 MB","cdmprintpdf":"0","cdmhasocr":"1","cdmisnewspaper":"0"}
